abstract.p: An experimental rotary damper device with a corrugated disc and a plate disc (called corrugated damper) has been examined. The narrow gap between the two discs is filled with an electrorheological fluid (or magnetorheological suspension); therefore, the electrostructural effect has to be taken into consideration. Computational fluid dynamics (FLUENT software) is used to produce comparative performance data between corrugated rotary damper and ordinary dual-plate rotary damper. Theoretical and numerical studies have shown that the total output torque increment for the corrugated disc rotary damper is significantly larger than that of the dual-disc rotary damper when the impact of the electric field strength is ignored. The results help the optimal design of a pre-prototyping structure with an electrorheological (or magnetorheological suspension) fluid damper.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Electrorheological fluid (ERF) or magnetorheological suspension (MRS) technology has been researched broadly in mechanical and vehicle engineering, including studies by Moosheimer and Waller (2000), Chen and Wei (2007), Chen and Bullough (2007), Ellam (2004), Choi et al. (2002), Choi et al. (2007), Hong et al. (2005), Choi et al. (2001), Hong et al. (2008) and many other researchers. However, the research on rotary dampers based on ERF (or MRS) has focused on disc or cylinder rotary dampers, which have double-plane acting surfaces (Chen and Bullough, 2010; Chen and Wei, 2006; Hong et al., 2005; Nie et al., 2009).

In order to get higher total output torque, recently, Shi Wei and Li Yang (Li and Huang, 2005; Shi and Chen, 2007) presented a new prototype of the damper in which a corrugated rotary disc replaces one of the plate discs.

Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) is used for the computations and results are verified against analytical solutions and experimental data where possible. A CFD model should be capable of solving these cases – for a small gap size and complex hydrodynamic geometry (Chen and Bullough, 2007, 2010). The fluid, which may be an ERF or MRS, is taken to be a Bingham plastic with temperature-invariant plastic viscosity and yield stress. For simplicity, input and output shafts are not included in the comparisons; however; they may have some effects on the acceleration and heat transfer.

This study uses FLUENT (A CFD software) as the operating program with sub-routines (user-defined programs) to handle the non-Newtonian nature of the fluid and to further compare the corrugated disc rotary damper with the dual-disc rotary damper based on the ERF (or MRS) effect. The results indicate that the output torque properties are different in both dampers; that is, theoretical and numerical solution studies have shown that the total output torque increment for the corrugated disc rotary damper is significantly larger than that of the dual-disc rotary damper when the impact of the electric field strength is ignored. Therefore, we can reduce huge consumption on the part of the experiment and benefit rotary ERF/MRS damper design optimization.

sec.p: It is sufficient to meet the simulation requirements by using the FLUENT software to solve the case with two-dimensional (2D) single precision because of its typical axial symmetry. The simulation settings are as follows: (a) the solver chosen is built in FLUENT; (b) uncoupled solution method and implicit algorithm are used; (c) spatial attribute is the axisymmetric rotary space; (d) time attribute is the steady flow, and the flow in two rotation surfaces is defined as the laminar flow mode, and (e) rectangle grids of 50 × 1525 (gridding numbers) are generated by GAMBIT. Furthermore, it is important to link the biviscosity model to the FLUENT via user-defined program (Chen and Bullough, 2007).

sec.title: A model of the corrugated disc rotary damper
sec.p: Corrugated disc rotary damper is improved from the general dual-disc rotary damper by substituting one of the plate discs with a corrugated disc. The corrugated disc rotary damper can increase torque due to the forces generated by shearing and complex squeezing between the two discs. On the basis of the theory of fluid dynamics, the pressure distribution of the rotary damper can be analysed and the model of a corrugated disc rotary damper is designed. The model consists of a stationary corrugated disc and a rotary flat disc. ERF (or magnetorheological fluid (MRF)) is filled into the gap between the two discs. Torque is transferred via shearing and squeezing pressure forces of the ERF (or MRF). Figure 2 shows the figuration of the corrugated disc.

sec.p: In FLUENT software, a single-precision solution is used and its solver adopts the non-coupled solution method and implicit algorithm. The attributes ‘3D’ and ‘flow unsteady’ are used as the spatial attribute selectors. The absolute speed of the model is established by calculation. The two rotating surfaces have laminar flow. The relationship between the input speed and torque is simulated and compared. Reasonable initial calculations of area, gauge pressure, axial and radial velocities and rotary speed are chosen. The size of the residual value to determine the convergence of computing can be controlled. The convergence can also be changed by the residual curve of the trend curve. In addition, for obtaining important surface parameters, the residual value can be chosen and monitored. Besides, the boundary conditions of the model are decided based on the material parameters and the fluid flowing features of the rotating surface.

sec.p: From Figures 6 and 8, it can be found that the highest positive pressure of 15,302 Pa is at point ‘a’, that is, surface ‘A’ in Figure 3, and the highest negative pressure of 4,215 Pa is at point ‘b’, that is, the surface ‘B’ in Figure 3. The distribution area of positive pressure is concentrated on the surface ‘A’ of the corrugated disc, and the distribution area of negative pressure is concentrated on the surface ‘B’, which is adjacent to surface ‘A’. The cavity of the corrugated disc created by two fan-shaped planes is investigated. The velocity distribution curve is offset upward on the cavity in Figure 9, which indicates the upward squeezing action of the ERF. The increasing static pressure can result in increase in pressure of the surface ‘A’ and decrease in pressure of the surface ‘B’, according to Bernoulli’s theorem (equation (2)). Because of the squeezing action by surfaces ‘A’ and ‘B’, an output torque of 0.01943 N m and a viscous torque of 0.27476 N m are produced by the corrugated disc.

sec.title: Comparison between corrugated disc and dual-disc rotary dampers
sec.p: The viscous torque and total torque under different rotary speeds are calculated at a given yield stress of 5000 Pa. The results are shown in Table 4 and Figures 10 and 11.

The relationship between total torque and rotary speed at constant yield stress.

sec.p: Simulation results of dual-disc damper show that the total torque equals the viscous torque (as shown in Table 4). However, the total torque is different between the corrugated plate rotating damper and plate damper, which is due to the viscous torque and an additional squeezing pressure torque on the corrugated plate surface.

For the dual-disc rotary damper, torque generated can be boosted only by increasing input rotary speed and therefore increasing the dynamic viscosity. However, for a corrugated disc rotary damper, total torque can be increased by viscous torque and an additional squeezing pressure torque. The results have been shown in Figures 10 and 11.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, it was shown that the torque generated by the corrugated disc rotary damper is superior to that of the conventional rotary dual-disc shear damper. ERF (or MRF) is squeezed directly between the corrugated surface and the flat clutch plate so that it can generate a squeezing pressure and an associated output torque, which does not exist in the conventional rotary dual-disc shear damper. The total torque and the viscous torque of the corrugated disc rotary damper increase dramatically with the rotary speed, whereas the dual-disc rotary damper shows only a small increase in both of these torques. Simulation shows that the total output torque of the corrugated disc rotary damper can be increased by 25%, when compared to the dual-disc rotary damper, for a rotary speed of 10,000 rpm.
